message: I wanted to see if anyone was interested in helping to set up a  vegetable garden on the rooftop. I've taken care of most of the plants, but we still need to build wind barriers and an automatic watering system.

I am absolutely interested.  I just inherited a roof deck of my own and am actively setting it up now, including a solar powered drip system.  I haven't been to the new digs yet -- is there water pressure on the roof?  If so, things will be much easier.  If not, we'll have to use a cistern.

I've also got a green thumb.  I'm open to any/all veggies, and I will have extra seedlings from my own deck.  I've already got two Sweet 100 cherry tomato babies that need a home, and will have surplus beefsteak tomatoes, Golden Honey cantalopes, and lemon cucumber sprouts shortly.  I started them two days ago.  I've also got two varieties of beans I haven't started yet, and corn.

whafa, unfortunately there's no water source on the roof, so we'll have to lug water up there. I've already started building a setup using self-watering containers hacked from Home Depot buckets, that are fed from a large water source- elevated 5 gallon water cooler bottles. The water feeding is controlled by float valves.
Here is a moisture sensor that might be hackable.  http://store.thesimplegarden.com/  (WaterStick)
And I'm sure you may have seen this, but the project may give ideas for sensors, and provide some code.  http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10334

Oh, I also started a chipin if anyone wants to donate a couple bucks. Especially since this is a "communal" garden and the fruits and vegetables are to be shared with everyone in the group. http://alphaonerooftopgarden.chipin.com/alphaone-rooftop-vegetable-garden
whafa, right now there's about a dozen plants- tomatoes, figs, raspberries, and blueberries. I'm always open to expanding, provided that people are willing to donate time and money.

Ari, looks very cool. I think psytek was working on a moisture sensor from another project- it'd be cool to hook up a thermometer and arduino and have it tweet conditions each day. Once the basic garden is set up, we can start adding the bells and whistles

You may benefit from improvised weapons & booby trap army field manuals. They'd probably be available in PDF free lots of places, or I have hard copies. They're all about making sensors & actuators out of stuff you find lying around.
If anyone is free this weekend, a couple of us are going to work to set up the garden Sunday (May 1) at 3:30pm. Just let me know if you'd like to come help out.
Mick, you mean to guard our vegetables from birds? Airmines?

Yeah, I made a sensor out of plaster of Paris and 2 zinc coated nails.  I'd be interested to see how it works out, we also have a bunch of solar panels we can use and a wishield could probably reach the lab from the roof.
Nah, I don't mean weaponry. I mean creative approaches to moisture/sun/wind sensors... But the sound of a bunch of birds taking flight may inspire others.
I'll be there with Jason on Sunday, would love a few extra hands
